Graphical abstract This review introduces the role of Mo-based materials as catalysts, co-catalysts, and carriers and summarizes design strategies of various Mo-based materials for OER applications in alkaline electrolytes. A thorough understanding of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in Mo-based materials is crucial for the advancement of water-splitting technologies. However, the identification of the active phase in Mo-based systems remains a subject of debate, largely due to the dissolution of molybdenum oxides in alkaline electrolytes. In this review, we provide a comprehensive overview of recent advances in the application of Mo-based materials for OER in alkaline media, with an emphasis on their diverse roles in catalysis. Various design strategies employed to optimize Mo-based materials are discussed, focusing on how these approaches influence their physicochemical properties and the specific effects of different design perspectives on their OER performance. Additionally, the structure-performance relationship underlying these materials is explored, offering insights into how structural modifications impact catalytic efficiency. Lastly, key challenges for Mo-based materials in OER applications are provided, and future research directions for further improving the efficacy of sustainable water-splitting technologies in alkaline environments are proposed. Keywords Mo-based materials Structure-performance relationship Oxygen evolution reaction Alkaline media Electrocatalysis 1 Introduction The global environmental and energy issues are plaguing the sustainable development of society. It is imperative to seek out clean energy sources and developing efficient, low-cost and sustainable energy conversion technologies [1–3]. Electrochemical redox reactions, particularly those involving water, oxygen, and hydrogen, include the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), which are central to a wide range of energy storage and conversion systems [3–9]. These reactions are pivotal in metal-air batteries and water splitting. To enable the efficient operation of these energy devices, the development of electrocatalysts capable of reducing the energy barrier of electrode reactions and enhancing energy conversion efficiency is essential. In contrast to the HER process, OER involves a more complex 4-electron transfer process, necessitating a higher overpotential [10–12]. As a result, future OER electrocatalysts should be equipped with faster electron and proton transfer, ensuring an optimized three-phase interface (gas, liquid, and solid) for optimal reaction kinetics. OER also represents a key half-reaction in metal-air batteries, critically influencing both energy storage and conversion efficiency. However, the sluggish kinetics of OER, particularly in alkaline media, present a significant bottleneck in the overall efficiency of water splitting and electrolysis technologies [13]. Addressing these challenges is pivotal for the advancement of renewable energy systems, including hydrogen production. Noble metal oxides, including IrO2 and RuO2, are widely acknowledged as benchmark electrocatalysts for OER. Nevertheless, their scarcity and high cost severely restrict their widespread commercial utilization [14]. This underscores the urgent need for the development of efficient, non-precious metal-based OER electrocatalysts [15,16]. Such materials offer the promise of scalable and sustainable solutions to meet global energy demands. Furthermore, rational design strategies targeting improved catalytic activity, stability, and cost-effectiveness are crucial to overcoming the limitations of current catalysts and unlocking the full potential of water-splitting technologies [17–19]. Molybdenum (Mo), a transition metal characterized by Pt-like d-band centers and an electronic structure, is extensively utilized in HER processes, including various Mo-based alloys, MoO x , MoS2, MoN, MoP, Mo x C, and their complexes [20–25]. However, research on Mo-based materials for the OER process remains relatively sparse. This scarcity primarily arises from easy oxidation of Mo-based materials in alkaline solutions during OER, leading to the gradual dissolution of formed Mo oxides, which compromises their cycling stability [26,27]. Additionally, the dissolution and subsequent reconstruction of Mo-based materials during OER complicate the identification of reaction intermediates. Despite the challenges, Mo-based materials have attracted considerable interest in their OER capabilities [28–30]. Recent studies have reported the application of Mo-related electrocatalysts for OER and water splitting (Fig. 3a). Notably, the introduction of Mo into amorphous metal oxides facilitates rapid surface self-reconstruction during the OER, forming a metal–oxygen (hydroxide) active layer enriched with oxygen vacancies [26], which is essential for efficient OER. However, extensive dissolution of Mo results in significant surface reconstruction, creating numerous metal vacancies, thereby altering the nature of the active center, which may no longer be associated with Mo. To mitigate Mo dissolution, researchers have proposed the self-sacrifice effect, where the reduction of the OH− concentration on the Mo surface due to the stronger affinity of Co. This effect demonstrated effectiveness in preventing Mo dissolution [31–33]. Nonetheless, this approach complicates the identification of active centers. Furthermore, modifying the coordination environment around Mo with various non-metallic elements presents a potential strategy to address dissolution issues [34,35]. However, the inherent tendency of Mo to oxidize in the presence of oxygen during conventional OER poses significant challenges in stabilizing its coordination environment, resulting in the formation of new intermediate products that have yet to be thoroughly studied. Moreover, the dissolution of Mo is not complete, and the role of residual Mo in the catalytic process is usually ignored. Therefore, it is imperative to deepen the understanding of the crystal structure of Mo-based materials and advance the analysis of the OER reaction mechanism. This knowledge is essential for the rational design of stable and efficient Mo-based materials, which can either prevent the oxidation of Mo or facilitate its peroxidation during the OER process. Furthermore, engineering new OER reaction mechanisms could enable the realization of highly efficient electrocatalytic performance in Mo-based materials. In this review, we initially introduce the role of Mo-based materials as catalysts, co-catalysts, and carriers in the OER process, starting with an analysis of the OER mechanism in an alkaline solution. Next, we explore how these materials affect the OER process and the underlying mechanisms when utilized as catalysts and co-catalysts. Then, various design strategies related to the morphology, interface, and defects of Mo-based materials for OER in alkaline media are discussed. Finally, the remaining challenges and prospects for developing efficient Mo-related electrocatalysts to advance low-cost water-splitting technologies are proposed (Fig. 1 ). 2 OER reaction mechanism 2.1 Pathways of OER mechanism OER is a relatively complex reaction process compared to the HER process, with the overall reaction equation in alkaline solution as follows. 4 OH - → O 2 + 2 H 2 O + 4 e - The entire process involves the transfer of 4 electrons (4e−), requiring a higher overpotential than HER. Currently, the widely recognized OER mechanisms in alkaline solutions mainly include the Adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM) (Fig. 2 a) and the lattice oxygen oxidation mechanism (LOM) [38,39]. In AEM, when the electronic state near the Fermi energy level exhibits metallic properties, the metal acts as the redox center. The catalytic performance is largely dependent on surface adsorption sites, following a volcano-type relationship [40]. AEM is considered as a conventional OER pathway. Conversely, in LOM, when oxygen dominates the electronic states near the Fermi level, oxygen serves as the redox center, and catalytic performance depends on the accessibility of non-bonded oxygen atoms. LOM, initially observed in Li-rich materials [39], has gained significant attention due to its advantages in overcoming the scaling relationship of adsorption energies in AEM, thus lowering the theoretical overpotential. Therefore, some studies have focused on enhancing the availability of oxygen non-binding states and activating lattice oxygen through strategies such as element doping and structural modulation. This approach shifted the reaction mechanism of OER from AEM to LOM, thus enhancing the electrocatalytic performance. To facilitate a deeper understanding of these catalysts and their mechanisms, typical OER electrocatalysts are summarized in Table 1 . This indicates that rational design can facilitate a shift in the reaction mechanism, thereby enabling the inhibition or controlled peroxidation of Mo oxidation. Based on LOM, when intra-molecular electron transfer induces active site reconfiguration and formation of ligand cavities, leading to lattice oxygen depletion, this process is referred to as the oxygen vacancy site mechanism (OVSM) (Fig. 2b) [45]. OVSM covers the most typical form of LOM. Active centers in these processes can be further classified as either a single-metal-site mechanism or a dual-metal-site mechanism, depending on whether single or dual sites are involved [46]. The scaling relation among adsorption intermediates hinders the conventional AEM pathway, leading to a higher theoretical overpotential—an issue effectively addressed by LOM. However, the inherent generation of oxygen vacancies of LOM presents a challenge, as it necessitates a careful balance between catalytic activity and structural stability [17,47,48]. Recently, several innovative mechanisms have emerged in OER research. One such mechanism is intra-molecular oxygen coupling, observed in Ni(M)OOH under alkaline conditions, which involves the direct coupling of neighboring adsorbed *O species (Fig. 2c). This mechanism is limited to layered double hydroxides (LDHs) [49]. Another is the coupled oxygen mechanism (Fig. 2e), where metal acts as the redox center during deprotonation, and oxygen facilitates O-O bond formation, which is particularly effective under light-triggered conditions [50]. Lastly, the oxide pathway mechanism (Fig. 2d) involving direct coupling of O-O radicals has been proposed for non-homogeneous catalysts, especially in acidic electrolytes [18,51]. Since it is difficult to capture the reaction intermediates of the OER process, different oxygen-containing intermediates are accompanied by redox reactions, which leads to the complexity of its reaction mechanism. Therefore, the pathway on the OER reaction mechanism is currently pending further refinement. 2.2 Estimation of OER mechanism OER mechanisms can usually be evaluated by the method shown in Fig. 3c. The present way of determining the AEM mechanism is mainly through the Tafel slope value, and the AEM consists of the following four main steps. (1) M + OH− → M−OH + e− (OH− adsorption) (2) M−OH + OH− → M−O + H2O(l) + e− (O–H bond broken) (3) M−O + OH− → M−OOH + e− (OH− secondary adsorption) (4) M−OOH + OH− → M + O2(g) + H2O(l) + e− (O2 formation) Where the slopes of the Tafel curves for (1), (2), and (4) are 120, 30, and 30 mV dec−1, respectively [52]. By comparing the experimentally obtained Tafel slopes with calculated values, the rate-determining step (RDS) and the underlying OER mechanism can be inferred [35]. However, since Tafel slopes can exhibit similar values at different overpotentials, it is impossible to identify the exact reaction mechanism based on Tafel slopes alone. Therefore, breaking the linear relationship of the Tafel slope necessitates the development of alternative methods. In the LOM process, proton and electron transfer occur in an uncoupled manner, with proton transfer exhibiting strong pH dependence (Fig. 4 a). Consequently, the LOM process is highly sensitive to the pH of the electrolyte [53,54]. Researchers have evaluated LOM by monitoring changes in the LSV curves of Ni(Fe)OOH in a KOH solution with slight concentration variations. Furthermore, it has been demonstrated that certain materials exhibit distinct properties at varying pH levels under unstable conditions, yet still adhere to AEM [22]. Tracking O2 2− and O2− production is essential for distinguishing between AEM and LOM. Tetramethylammonium ions (TMA+) are particularly prone to bind with oxygen-negative ions, potentially hindering the OER process in LOM, as depicted in Fig. 4b [55,56]. Therefore, adding TMA+ to the KOH solution and subsequently testing the electrocatalytic performance of the material were used to determine the OER mechanism. Up to now, sophisticated instruments have emerged as powerful tools for distinguishing AEM and LOM mechanisms (Fig. 5 ). Reaction intermediates can be directly captured using in-situ attenuated total reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR FTIR) and Raman spectroscopy, providing a clearer understanding of the underlying reaction mechanisms [57]. Additionally, in-situ surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) facilitates the direct observation of *O–O bond formation due to its molecular fingerprint specificity and high sensitivity [58]. Isotope-labeled tracer methods can track oxygen dynamics throughout the OER process, offering deeper insights into oxygen evolution [51,59]. Furthermore, chemical probes designed to identify intermediates provide valuable information on OER intermediates and reaction pathways [60]. Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations are utilized to determine the binding energy between intermediates and catalysts. This approach enables the estimation of the lowest theoretical overpotential of OER, facilitating the expression of OER reactivity in terms of Gibbs free energy (ΔG). Different reaction mechanisms involve distinct reaction intermediates, which are associated with different ΔG values. Consequently, these reaction mechanisms can be elucidated through DFT calculations. Deng et al. [61] extensively selected transition metals by DFT simulations and demonstrated that metal dopants and oxygen vacancies in Co3O4 can shift the mechanism of OER from AEM to LOM. Duan et al. [22] revealed that the presence of nonbonding oxygen states and oxygen states at the Fermi level makes the lattice oxygen susceptible to involve in the OER process by DFT calculations. Therefore, ZnCo2- x Ni x O4 follows AEM when x < 0.4 and LOM when 0.6 < x < 0.8. 3 Application of Mo-based materials in OER Mo-based materials are considered as promising OER catalysts due to their multiple redox valence states and high oxidation state. Mo-based materials, such as molybdenum nitride [62] and molybdenum carbide [63], exhibit excellent electrical conductivity, which is a key property for electrocatalysts as it directly influences the rate of electron transfer between reactants and electrodes, resulting in favorable reaction kinetics. Therefore, Mo-based materials can be directly used as OER electrocatalysts. Additionally, as a 4d transition metal, Mo element can improve both conductivity and stability when alloyed with 3d metals, such as Fe, Co, and Ni. This synergistic combination improves the adsorption energy of reaction intermediates on the catalyst surface, further boosting catalytic performance [64,65]. At this point, Mo-based materials act as excellent co-catalysts to enhance the electrocatalytic OER performance of the system. Moreover, Mo-based materials can also be used as OER electrocatalyst carriers, which play a crucial role in improving catalytic activity and stability through metal-carrier interactions [66]. Mo-based materials were categorized into three parallel components according to their different roles in the OER process. When the Mo-based material itself acts as a reactive center, it is defined as a Mo-based catalyst. When the Mo-based material modulates the activity of other metal centers, it is defined as a Mo-based co-catalyst. When Mo-based materials do not participate in the OER reaction process, they are defined as Mo-based carriers. 3.1 Mo-based catalyst Most studies have shown that Mo-based materials have excellent OER electrocatalytic activity in combination with other materials. Ouyang et al. [67] found that the introduction of Co enhanced the OER electrocatalytic activity of β-Mo2C by combining Co and β-Mo2C. Cong et al. [68] proposed to directly control the intrinsic electronic structure of Mo2C and optimize the energy of the thermodynamic reaction by substituting Mo atoms via neighboring Ni atoms, resulting in favorable OER activity and superior stability. First, because the introduction of Co and Ni modulates the electronic structure of Mo, activates the Mo sites, enhances the adsorption of intermediates and accelerates the reaction thermodynamics of the decisive speed step. Secondly, due to the introduction of heteroatoms, heterogeneous structures are formed within the crystal structure, which can effectively promote electron transfer. Due to the thermodynamic instability of Mo-based materials in alkaline electrolytes, their direct application as OER electrocatalysts remains controversial. Metal single-atom (SA) catalysts are extensively used due to their excellent atomic level utilization and electrocatalytic activity. The tunability of its composition and structure can modify the adsorption/desorption selectivity of the active site, thereby affecting the reaction kinetics. Numerous ongoing studies focus on engineering highly efficient SA catalysts specifically for enhancing electrocatalytic activity in OER. Lu et al. [69] anchored Mo-SAs and W-SAs on catalytically active NiFe-MOF porous carriers, demonstrating that the synergistic modulation of the electronic structure between the SAs and active carriers significantly enhanced the catalytic efficiency. Meanwhile, Mo/W SAs contributed additional active sites (Fig. 6 a). Qin et al. [34] reported an O/N/S co-coordinated Mo-SAs with a hollow spherical structure (Fig. 6b). This coordination environment engineering optimizes the intrinsic electronic structure of the Mo SA sites, which leads to a significant improvement in OER performance. Yin et al. [70] highlighted that the maximized exposure of the 2H-phase of MoS2 significantly increases the number and stability of edge active sites, edge electron density, specific surface area, and conductivity of the catalyst, resulting in excellent OER performance in alkaline media. Furthermore, combining Mo-based materials with other catalysts has been shown to synergistically enhance electrocatalytic performance. Li et al. [71] demonstrated that the combination of Mo-SAs and Fe-SAs can effectively lower the energy barrier in water-splitting reactions and enhance overall performance (Fig. 6c). Sun et al. [72] composited Mo-SA with Co9S8, leveraging the synergistic charge transfer coupling effect between the two compounds to promote the conversion of H2O to oxygen radicals via proton transfer on the Co site after adsorption. This process is further facilitated by Mo SA tuning, which reduces the overpotential for water cleavage and enhances oxygen precipitation on the Co3+ site with higher electron density (Fig. 6d). Collectively, these studies underscore the significant potential of Mo-based materials for OER electrocatalysis. 3.2 Mo-based co-catalysts Several studies suggest that Mo-based materials generally exhibit lower intrinsic catalytic activity than their 3d metal-based counterparts, such as Fe, Co, and Ni. However, their high oxidation states enable them to modulate the electronic structure of the system, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity of the active centers [73] (Fig. 7 a). He et al. [74] incorporated Mo and W into MAF-6-Co (Co-MOF), and revealed that the introduction of Mo increased the oxidation state of Co and enhanced its affinity for polar water molecules. Additionally, the presence of Mo results in poor overlap between d-orbitals of Co and p-orbitals of O near the Fermi energy level, leading to a decrease in O2 adsorption energy and optimal catalytic performance for CoMo-imidazolate frameworks (CoMo-Im). Tian et al. [75] found that at lower Mo/Co ratios, the Mo component can shift the d-band center of the catalyst upward (Fig. 7b), thus enhancing the ability to activate H2O and improving the OER performance. Furthermore, the dissolution of molybdenum oxides in alkaline solutions contributes to the OER process. Wang et al. [76] demonstrated that in-situ formed MoO3 on the surface of the CoMo-LDH phase could effectively block Cl−, thereby reducing catalyst corrosion. This allows H2O/OH− to enter the active interface of the catalyst, as shown in Fig. 7c, enabling direct seawater splitting. Yu et al. [26] proposed that the rapid dissolution of Mo from amorphous NiFeMo oxides during the OER process accelerates surface reconstruction, resulting in the formation of a metal–oxygen (hydroxide) reactive layer with abundant oxygen vacancies, which leads to superior OER activity. 3.3 Mo-based carriers Transition metal oxides (TMOs) have garnered significant attention for their commendable durability and excellent corrosion resistance. Abundant defect sites and –OH groups on the surface of TMO substrates serve as effective anchoring points for individual metal atoms. As a carrier, molybdenum oxide only participates in the sample synthesis process but not in the OER reaction process. MoO x is mostly used as a template, which maximizes the exposure of real active centers and thus promotes the OER process [77]. He et al. [78] used MoO2 as a hard template to form a nanorod-like 3D structure, and the ESCA of the synthesized Ce-NiO@MoO2 was significantly increased. Kim et al. [79] mixed MoO x with TiO2 to improve the electrical conductivity of the TiO2 carrier and lead to a higher Ir(III) content in its surface-loaded Ir nanoparticles. Mu et al. [80] stabilized Ru SAs using amorphous molybdenum-based oxides (Ru SAs-MoO3-x/NF), resulting in catalysts with large surface areas, high activity, and fast reaction kinetics, effectively driving OER in alkaline media (Fig. 8 a). Xu et al. [81] also reported that the MoO3 carrier can significantly enhance the intrinsic activity of RuO2. Liu et al. [82] indicated that Mn-doped MoO2 is a robust carrier to ensure good durability of the system. Wen et al. [83] proposed that the surface plasmon resonance effect of MoO2 generates high-energy electrons and holes, which accelerates the conversion of inactive low-valent Co to active cobalt oxides, significantly enhancing the electrocatalytic activity of the material during the OER process. The roles of different components are shown in Fig. 8b. Apart from oxides, molybdenum carbide (Mo2C) is also considered as a promising carrier for OER electrocatalysts due to its excellent electrical conductivity and Pt-like electronic structure. Tian et al. [84] suggested that Mo2C carriers could significantly increase the surface area and improve the electronic conductivity of CoP/Mo2CT x catalysts. This enhancement raises the total density of states and lowers the d-band center, thereby promoting the catalytic performance of active centers. In addition to increasing the electrochemical surface area (ECSA), Mo2C can interact with the host catalyst, thereby enhancing the overall OER performance. Liu et al. [66] proposed that metal-support interaction (MSI) between highly dispersed NiCoFe and metal carbide can achieve long-term durability, in which Mo2C can obtain the maximum MSI effect. Hou et al. [63] revealed that Mo2C was oxidized and dissolved during the OER process, promoting the ability to reconstitute NiSA-O into smaller Ni clusters with higher OER activity. Mo-based materials serve various roles depending on their applications during OER. When they are used as carriers, the actual active centers are the other metal elements loaded on the Mo-based materials. In this configuration, Mo-based materials provide structural scaffolds that enhance the dispersion and accessibility of active metal centers. When employed as co-catalysts, Mo-based materials modulate the electronic structure of the overall system, thereby regulating the d-band centers of 3d metals and endowing them with higher electrocatalytic activity. Conversely, when Mo-based materials are utilized as catalysts, researchers typically focus on their OER performance, often overlooking detailed mechanistic analyses [85,86]. Some studies have also proposed Mo-based materials as the active center of OER [31,87], attributing their excellent performance to synergistic effects between components. The OER process adheres to the LOM mechanism after doping Fe in Mo-based materials [32]. However, a comprehensive and systematic analysis of the OER mechanistic pathways for Mo-based materials remains limited due to the solubility of high-valence Mo oxides in alkaline electrolytes. To help readers understand the application of Mo-based materials in OER, we summarize the OER electrocatalysts with Mo-related materials in 1 M KOH in recent years in Table 2 (Fig. 9). 4 Design of Mo-based materials for OER The catalytic activity of OER electrocatalysts is primarily dictated by their intrinsic activity and electrical conductivity. Intrinsic activity is largely related to their geometrical and electronic structures, while electrical conductivity is related to the interfacial charge transfer during the catalytic reaction. Furthermore, the enhancement of the mass transfer efficiency between the three phases (solid, liquid, and gas) is also crucial to increase the OER activity. The design of electrocatalysts usually enhances the OER activity by introducing other components that regulate the electronic structure of the material, which in turn modulate the metallic d-band centers and the nonmetallic p-band centers to ease the adsorption/desorption of oxygen-containing intermediates. Furthermore, the morphology of the electrocatalyst can be modulated to expose more electrochemically active surfaces and edges for catalytic reactions. Grasping the structure-performance relationships (SPR) of materials is the key to designing efficient OER electrocatalysts [108]. Therefore, the design of Mo-based materials often emphasizes the optimization of both structure and morphology features (Fig. 3c). 4.1 Heterogeneous structures Heterostructures typically combine two or more materials, with each component playing a distinct role and synergistically enhancing the host material's electrocatalytic properties. As depicted in Fig. 10 a, Guo et al. [109] employed a quenching method to induce disorder and rough surface of large-grained NiMoO4 nanoparticles. Simultaneously, smaller NiMoO4 nanoparticles (< 27 nm) transform into the NiFe2O4 structure, resulting in the formation of a NiMoO4/NiFe2O4 heterostructure. This structure is rich in defects, increases the number of active sites, improves intrinsic activity, promotes electron transfer, and exhibits excellent OER activity. The overpotential is reduced by 103 mV after quenching five times (from 330 mV for NiMoO4/NiFe2O4 heterostructure catalyst prepared by quenching five times (MoNiO4-Fe-5th) (NiMoO4-NC)to 227 mV for NiMoO4/NiFe2O4). Yin et al. [37] designed a nitrogen-doped carbon-coated Ni/MoO2 nanorods with three-phase heterojunctions (Fig. 10b). Electron redistribution on the interfaces optimized the adsorption energy of oxygen-containing intermediates, lowered the free energy of the RDS, enabling the OER performance to outperform any single-phase material. By integrating the structural advantages of amorphous materials with the synergistic and electronic effects of crystal-crystal heterostructures, the development of amorphous-crystalline heterostructures has garnered significant attention [111,112]. The appearance of amorphous states changes the relative position of the d-band center of metals and the p-band center of O, increasing the possibility of lattice oxygen oxidation [22]. This leads to a change in the OER mechanism of amorphous-crystalline heterostructures. The amorphous-crystalline heterostructures of α-NiO x /α-Fe2O3 nanowire arrays enhance the trapping capacity of OH− in solution, and the accumulated OH− can promote the formation of Ni4+, change the reaction pathway, and make the OER process more favorable to follow the LOM, thereby accelerating the reaction kinetics [56]. Yang et al. [110] engineered an amorphous-crystalline structured NiFeMoO x . This heterogeneous structure allows for the rational regulation of the amorphous degree through Mo leaching, facilitating rapid surface remodeling of the pre-catalyst. Concurrently, the large number of oxygen vacancies generated by the phase transition greatly accelerates the deprotonation of *OH, resulting in rapid OER kinetics (Fig. 10c). The amorphous/crystalline- NiFeMoO x (a/c-NiFeMoO x ) exhibits an overpotential merely of 256 mV for OER and a cell voltage of 1.52 V for water electrolysis to reach 10 mA cm−2. 4.2 Defect regulation Defect modulation stands as a key strategy to tailor the electronic structure of materials. The simplest defect production is achieved via high-temperature calcination in inert atmospheres, enabling volatile gases to be removed from the structure. Element doping is a prevalent technique for creating crystal defects, which causes Jahn-Teller distortion due to the size and electronegativity differences between atoms [113]. Defect modulation specifically refers to the introduction of point defects (e.g., metal, oxygen, and sulfur vacancies), line defects, and facet defects into the integrity crystal structure, which change the electronic structure of active sites in the original crystal structure to enable superior OER activity. Metal vacancies exhibit higher energy formation and are more stable than oxygen vacancies, and the adsorption energy for oxygen intermediates during OER is higher than that of surface metals [114]. Metal vacancies usually distort the crystal structure and modulate the electronic structure, especially the d-band center, enabling a suitable binding energy with the reaction intermediates [115,116]. are Oxygen vacancies, the most typical non-metallic vacancies, are generally formed with the accompany by doing strongly electronegative non-metallic elements into the pristine materials. Huang et al. [117] identified that phosphorus doping in FeMoO4 generated oxygen vacancies, which accelerated the dissolution of Mo during the OER process. This leads to rapid reconfiguration of P-FMO@NF, simultaneously modulates the electronic structure and enhances interfacial charge transfer. Thus, the presence of oxygen vacancies reduces the overpotential from 230 mV (FeMoO4 loaded on nickel foam) to 206 mV (P-doped FeMoO4 loaded on nickel foam) at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. Wang et al. [35] introduced element F by pyrolyzing NH4F and CoMoO4 to form Fluorine-doped cobalt molybdate. It induces the generation of abundant oxygen vacancies, exposing more active sites, reducing the band gap of CoMoO4, and increasing the electrical conductivity. These modifications optimize the intrinsic activity of CoMoO4, so F-CoMoO4 exhibits excellent OER properties with overpotential η = 256 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Owing to the widespread application of MoS2 in various fields, S defects are also commonly found in Mo-based materials. Mahmood et al. [118] utilized first-principles calculations to assess the impact of S defects with varying structures on WS2/MoS2 heterostructures (Fig. 11 b). The presence of interfacial defects could enhance the overall OER performance. These defects enhance the interaction between WS2 and MoS2 layers, facilitate charge transfer, and diminish the OER overpotential. Additionally, lattice distortions induced by the exchange of oxygen-containing anions in the orthotetrahedron structure enable defect modulation and improve the electrochemical properties [119,120]. He et al. [121] calculated the spin density of the electronic state of P-CoMoO4 and revealed that P was incorporated as PO4 3−. The PO4 3− substitutes for MoO4 2− with high stability, creates electron holes on the surface of ions and enhances the performance of water splitting. The defect-rich character of crystalline materials has also attracted much attention, and amorphous materials are inherently defect-rich. Therefore, the preparation of amorphous electrocatalysts is an effective way for defect modulation. Yu et al. [26] pioneered a scalable synthesis approach for amorphous NiFeMo oxides, which underwent a faster surface self-reconstruction process during OER to form a metal–oxygen (hydroxide) active layer with abundant oxygen vacancies. The derived catalyst delivers superior OER activity (280 mV to 10 mA cm−2 in 0.1 m KOH). This reconstruction is favorable for improving the intrinsic activity of the catalyst by reasonably tuning the amorphous degree so that it has sufficient oxygen vacancies [110]. Moreover, the amorphous transformation of the OER process can be realized by doping with other elements. Hartnett et al. [122] improved the OER activity by doping with La3+ ions, which disrupted the Co3O4 lattice. 4.3 Morphological control Morphological modulation is a pivotal strategy for enhancing catalytic activity by altering the surface microstructure, optimizing the three-phase mass-transfer efficiency, or enhancing the electrical conductivity to boost OER reaction kinetics. Reducing the particle size and increasing the number of reaction edges can expose more active sites and thus improve the OER performance. It has also been reported that the wrinkle-like multilevel micro- and nanoscale composite structure can realize the effective infiltration of electrolytes and rapid removal of gas bubbles, and accelerate mass transfer at the three-phase boundary [123]. The different nanoparticle sizes also correspond to different ECSA [124]. Kou et al. [125] introduced ZIF-8 into phosphomolybdic acid through constrained pyrolysis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), yielding size-controllable Mo-based catalysts ranging from isolated SA to sub-nanoclusters (< 1 nm) and nanoparticles (2–5 nm) (Fig. 12 a). This process increases the contact area between the material and electrolyte, increasing the number of active sites. Additionally, the introduction of a carbon skeleton enhances electrical conductivity, enabling the Mo-SA catalysts with superior OER activity. Compared to other catalysts (1.56 and 1.64 V for Mo and sub-nanometer MoC clusters anchored on the nitrogen-doped carbon matrix, respectively), Mo single atom catalysts anchored on the nitrogen-doped carbon matrix requires the lowest overpotential (1.48 V) to achieve 10 mA cm−2. MXene is one of the typical 2D materials, and the design of 2D Mo-based MXenes can also enhance the OER performance. Yi et al. [126] identified Mo2CT x MXene as a good support material with excellent metal conductivity, chemical stability, and hydrophilicity, which can be utilized as a potential catalyst carrier for anchoring single atoms. Park et al. [127] proposed that the strong Mo-Co interaction between Mo2CT x MXene and Co nanoparticles significantly enhanced the intrinsic OER catalytic activity of Co. Morphological modulation of Mo-based materials can be realized by introducing Mo elements into MOF materials with certain morphological structures. Chen et al. [128] synthesized CoO x -MoC heterostructures derived from nitrogen-doped carbon-coated Mo-doped Co-MOF, as depicted in the synthesis schematic in Fig. 12b. The morphology of Co-MOF is modified by adding a Mo source, which forms a nanowire-assembled hierarchical porous microstructure. This modification enlarges the specific surface area, exposes more active sites, and promotes mass transport and charge transfer. The formation of CoO x -MoC heterostructures accelerates the reaction kinetics with a Tafel slope value of 89.08 mV dec−1 during OER which is much better than other comparative samples. Meanwhile, the beneficial microstructure ensures superior long-term electrochemical stability. Moreover, morphology modulation during hydrothermal synthesis is frequently achieved by manipulating the product ratio or solvent type. Yin et al. [70] synthesized molybdenum disulfide nano-islands with nanopores by controlling the molar ratio of Mo/S precursors during the hydrothermal synthesis process. This morphological adjustment increases the number of active sites and stability of effective edge active sites, edge electron density, specific surface area, and conductivity of the electrocatalyst. The Cdl value of the porous MoS2 nano-islands (M1S1) is 41.7 mF cm−2, which is almost twice as much as that of other MoS2 catalysts, as measured by ECSA (Fig. 12c). 4.4 Ion adsorption Compared to other electrocatalysts, the instability of Mo-based materials in alkaline solutions gives them the advantage of ion adsorption during OER. MoO4 2− anions leached in the alkaline electrolyte can adsorb onto the surface of the material or intercalate within it, thereby affecting the OER process [36]. Surface-adsorbed anions have the potential to be further polymerized, exerting a more pronounced impact on the OER process. Specifically, when polyanions are incorporated into the material, they can offer high redox potentials [129]. Through a series of in-situ experiments (Fig. 13 a), Hu et al. [130] discovered that Mo metal in FeCoNiCrMo alloy is rapidly oxidized and dissolved into the electrolyte, triggering concomitant Cr dissolution and leaving reconfigured NiFeCo hydroxyl-oxidized nanostructures on the surface during the OER process. This catalyst requires an overpotential of 303 mV to reach 100 mA cm−2 and maintains stable activity for at least 120 h. Mo adsorbed and/or inserted into the active layer in the form of MoO4 2− anion accelerates the redox transition of Ni2+/Ni 3+ and facilitates the generation of an active β- NiOOH phase, thereby improving the OER activity. Qi et al. [64] effectively tuned the electronic structure of the material by doping cobalt oxide with Ru and Mo. As shown in Fig. 13b, during the OER process, the material undergoes surface reconstruction, and the coupling of controllable Mo dissolution with the generated oxygen vacancies can optimize the adsorption energy of the oxygen intermediates, which significantly accelerates the OER kinetics. Pan et al. [131] proposed that the leaching of MoO4 2− enhances the reconstruction of NiMo-Fe. The overpotential of Ni-Fe is 250 mV when the concentration MoO4 2− is 0.05 M in the KOH solution, which is 22 mV lower than that of Ni-Fe in the pure KOH electrolyte at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. It was verified by DFT calculations that the surface reabsorption of MoO4 2− promotes the adsorption of *OOH intermediates and enhances the OER activity (Fig. 13c). In summary, the adsorption of molybdate can promote the reconfiguration of the host material during the OER process, improve the adsorption energy of the reaction intermediates, and enhance the OER kinetics. Furthermore, it has been demonstrated that some anions (Bo4 3-, NO2–, CO3 2–, MoO4 2-, etc.) adsorbed on the electrode surface due to the interactions of physic/chemical adsorption, electrostatic adsorption, etc., preferentially adsorb on the surface of the electrodes, changing the localized pH, and improving the corrosion resistance and durability of transition metals in seawater [132,133]. The effects of the design strategies described above do not stand alone and are usually accompanied by interactionsthat ultimately has a combined impact on the OER process. The loading of nickel onto nickel molybdenum nitride (Ni/Ni0.8Mo4.2N6) results in strong interactions within the heterogeneous structures, which contribute to exceptional catalytic kinetics. Meanwhile, this structural feature makes the Ni/Ni0.8Mo4.2N6 surface super hydrophilic, facilitating the penetration of the electrolyte and favoring the mass transfer process at the three-phase boundary [134]. Mei et al. [135] discovered that dual activation of various mechanisms of OER could be achieved at various sites by introducing metal elements into high-entropy alloys. Meanwhile, multi-element interactions also significantly enhanced the structural stability. 5 Conclusions and perspectives This review summarizes the progress of Mo-based materials for OER in an alkaline medium, highlighting their multifaceted roles as catalysts, co-catalysts and carriers. The design of different Mo-based materials for OER electrocatalysts is emphasized, focusing on aspects of the crystal structure and material morphology. Previous studies have predominantly emphasized the superior performance of Mo-based materials, attributing this advantage to their high oxidation states and unique electronic structures, which effectively modulates the d-band center of adjacent metals. However, the intrinsic reaction mechanisms of Mo-based materials during OER remain underexplored. While some studies propose that the OER mechanism follows LOM, the comprehensive visualization of the OER process has been impeded by limitations in experimental techniques, including in-situ characterization and isotopic tracer labeling. Additionally, certain studies classify the OER process of Mo-based materials in alkaline electrolytes as following the AEM, contributing to ongoing debates regarding the underlying mechanisms. To advance the understanding of Mo-based materials in the OER process, further research is warranted in the following aspects (Fig. 14 ). (1) Thermodynamic stability: There is limited knowledge regarding the crystal structure, solubility, and thermodynamic stability of Mo-based materials. While it is established that MoO3 is soluble in alkaline solutions, further investigation is needed to determine whether specific crystal surfaces enhance the thermodynamic stability of Mo-based materials in such environment. (2) Oxidation states: Considering that oxygen enrichment could increase the oxidation state of Mo to be + 6, structural modeling and experimental cultivation of single crystals can be employed to analyze crystal surface properties. This approach may help to ensure whether Mo is fully oxidized under certain conditions, forming a stabilized intermediate valence state in alkaline electrolytes or not. (3) Defect influence: The effects of defects generated during the OER process, particularly when Mo is leached from the material, remain inadequately defined. Many researchers posit that dissolved MoO4 2− is inactive and that dissolution exposes more active sites. The dynamic interplay between dissolution and the simultaneous OER complicates the separation of these processes. Detailed analysis can be achieved through controlled reaction processes or modeling. (4) Phase transformation: Occasionally, the OER process encourages the transformation of crystalline materials into amorphous states, but the mechanisms behind remain unclear yet. Further studies are required to assess the implications of this phase change on the water-splitting process. (5) Mechanistic studies: It is necessary to explore more accurate characterization techniques to track OER reaction intermediates in Mo-based materials. Combining in-situ techniques with DFT calculations can explore OER reaction mechanisms on an atomic scale, including identification of active sites, kinetics of the reaction process, tracking of reaction pathways, trapping of reaction intermediates, and evaluation of free energies of RDS, etc. (6) Electrochemical testing profiling Directly through electrochemical testing, such as cyclic voltammetry, the sweep rate is varied to analyze the changes in positions, intensities and areas of differnt redox peaks. The chemical signals are converted into electrical signals to analyze redox reactions during the OER process. This can avoid the uncertainty caused by signal delay and obliteration in other characterization methods. In conclusion, we advocate for comprehensive theoretical and experimental investigations into Mo-based materials to guide the rational design of high-performance OER catalysts. A thorough understanding of their structural intricacies is essential for elucidating OER mechanisms and advancing the development of bifunctional catalysts for water splitting, thus paving new avenues in the field of energy conversion. Qingcui Liu received her M.S. degree from Shihezi University, she is currently Ph.D. candidate in Physical Chemistry (Xinjiang University) under the supervision of Prof. Yudai Huang. Her research interests are focused on electrocatalyst design and exploitation. Wenhua Cheng is currently an associate professor at the School of Materials Science and Engineering, Xinjiang University, where he received his Ph.D. degree in 2023. His research interests include the study of lithium/sodium storage performance based on Mn-based layered oxide cathode materials. Yudai Huang is a professor at the State Key Laboratory of Chemistry and Utilization of Carbon Based Energy Resources at Xinjiang University. He received his Ph.D. from Xi'an Jiaotong University in 2009 and did postdoctoral work at Korea Institute of Science and Technology in 2011. Now he is the director of the Energy Materials group at Xinjiang University. His current research primarily focuses on electrochemistry, materials physics and chemistry. Huan Zhou is currently a graduate student in the research group of Professor Yudai Huang at the College of Chemistry, Xinjiang University. His research interests focus on the morphology control and near-surface modification of lithium-rich layered oxides. Juan Ding received her Ph.D. degree in 2022 from the College of Chemistry, Xinjiang University. She is currently working at Xinjiang University as an associate professor. Her research interests include the manufacture of nanostructured electrodes and their applications for energy conversion and storage. Weiwei Meng received his Ph.D. from Harbin Institute of Technology, His research interests focus on electrochemical energy storage and electrocatalytic research. Zhouliang Tan received his Ph.D. from the School of Metallurgy and Environment at Central South University, specializing in the structural design and performance optimization of layered oxide cathode materials.

coredata.dc:description: A thorough understanding of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in Mo-based materials is crucial for the advancement of water-splitting technologies. However, the identification of the active phase in Mo-based systems remains a subject of debate, largely due to the dissolution of molybdenum oxides in alkaline electrolytes. In this review, we provide a comprehensive overview of recent advances in the application of Mo-based materials for OER in alkaline media, with an emphasis on their diverse roles in catalysis. Various design strategies employed to optimize Mo-based materials are discussed, focusing on how these approaches influence their physicochemical properties and the specific effects of different design perspectives on their OER performance. Additionally, the structure-performance relationship underlying these materials is explored, offering insights into how structural modifications impact catalytic efficiency. Lastly, key challenges for Mo-based materials in OER applications are provided, and future research directions for further improving the efficacy of sustainable water-splitting technologies in alkaline environments are proposed.
